questions.question_text: Which Snowflake multi-cluster virtual warehouse scaling policy or mode will MINIMIZE query queuing by prioritizing the startup of additional clusters?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Standard policy (B):
Minimizes query queuing by prioritizing the startup of additional clusters as soon as they are needed.

Selected Answer: B
The question must be refined. Or a scaling policy - and the answer is B, or the scaling mode and the answer is D.

comments.content: Corection: if it is about MODE, it is AUTO-SCALE MODE C.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses-overview
Precedence for warehouse defaults
When a user connects to Snowflake and start a session, Snowflake determines the default warehouse for the session in the following order:

Default warehouse for the user,

» overridden by…

Default warehouse in the configuration file for the client utility (SnowSQL, JDBC driver, etc.) used to connect to Snowflake (if the client supports configuration files),

» overridden by…

Default warehouse specified on the client command line or through the driver/connector parameters passed to Snowflake.

choices.C: Default warehouse specified on a CLI or in drivers/connectors parameters
choices.D: Default warehouse of the role assigned to the user
choices.B: Default warehouse in the configuration file of the client utilities

questions.question_text: Which default warehouse configuration has the highest precedence whenever a new session is created by a user?
Which type of query would benefit from enabling the query acceleration service on the virtual warehouse?

comments.content: And the D answer is exactly one of the 4 types of queries not supported by QA

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
It is not D. In docs.snowflake, there is exactly the text from Answer C.
My answer is C

choices.B: Queries that are queued in the warehouse
choices.D: Queries that contain a high cardinality GROUP BY expression
choices.C: Queries that use more resources than the typical query
choices.A: Queries with no filters or aggregation

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
RESULT_SCAN can be used to access the results of a query executed within the last 24 hours

questions.question_text: Which table function will return the output of a previously-run command?

choices.D: Use the GET command with the file_format set as JSON.
choices.C: Use the PUT command with the file_format set as JSON.
choices.A: Use the OBJECT_CONSTRUCT function in conjunction with the COPY INTO [location] command.
choices.B: Use the COPY INTO [location] command with the file_format set as JSON.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Unloading a relational table to JSON
You can use the OBJECT_CONSTRUCT function combined with the COPY command to convert the rows in a relational table to a single VARIANT column and unload the rows into a file.
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/data-unload-considerations

Selected Answer: B
The question does not say anything about an Object_Construct. Right answer is B.

comments.content: Please, disregard. The question does not say anything about an Object_Construct. Right answer is B.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
-- Unload the data to a file in a stage
COPY INTO @mystage
 FROM (SELECT OBJECT_CONSTRUCT('id', id, 'first_name', first_name, 'last_name', last_name, 'city', city, 'state', state) FROM mytable)
 FILE_FORMAT = (TYPE = JSON);

-- The COPY INTO location statement creates a file named data_0_0_0.json.gz in the stage.

Selected Answer: A
A, seen many times

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
